section.title: Future probability/possibility/certainty
section.sectiontitle: Use will to talk about something that is definite or a very strong probability.
section.text2a: Someone will meet you at the airport.
section.sectiontitle2: Use could, may or might to talk about something that is possible but not certain.
section.text3a: He might ask you to sign a temporary contract.
section.text4a: I may have time to stop at the bank on the way.

section.title: Future probability/possibility/certainty
section.sectiontitle: There are many other phrases for describing possibility. Adverbs/adverbial phrases: It will almost definitely, it almost definitely won't, presumably it will
section.text1a: Presumably, she will be leaving at the end of the month.
section.text2a: It almost definitely won't affect our plans.
section.sectiontitle2: Verb phrases: It may well, it might well, I doubt
section.text3a: This might well be the last time we meet.
section.text4a: I doubt we will come up with an answer today.

section.title: Future probability/possibility/certainty
section.sectiontitle: Other types of phrases include: Adjectives/adjectival phrases It's bound to, certain to, sure to, unlikely to, etc.
section.text1a: We are bound to need some help.
section.text2a: They are unlikely to contact us again.
section.sectiontitle2: Noun phrases: The chances are that, there's a strong/slight possibility, you haven't a hope of -ing
section.text3a: They haven't a hope of finding a cheaper flat.
section.text4a: The chances are that Murray will win the competition.
